In human postmortem middle frontal lobe tissues, caveolin-1 protein levels were higher in both APOE3/3 and APOE3/4 carriers with AD dementia than in the NCI group, although there was no difference between the APOE3/3 and APOE3/4 genotypes in either group (Fig. 3 [rid=Fig3] M; full blots are shown in Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] C).

context_description:
To explore the underlying mechanism, we treated ABCA1-GFP overexpressing HeLa cells with recombinant ApoE3 (rE3) or ApoE4 (rE4). rE4 treatment resulted in lower total ABCA1 protein levels than rE3 treatment, indicating greater ABCA1 degradation (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] A). ABCA1-binding complexes were enriched for proteomic analysis (Fig. 3 [rid=Fig3] A and Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] B). Proteomic analysis revealed 768 shared proteins between rE3 and rE4 treatments, with 314 proteins unique to rE4 (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] C). Nine of these proteins (Supplementary Table 4) showed higher expression in the rE4 treatment group than in the rE3 group (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] D). Reducing caveolin-1, but not, AP2B1 expression by siRNA increased plasma membrane ABCA1 levels in mouse primary astrocytes (Fig. 3 [rid=Fig3] F, Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] E), supporting that caveolae-mediated endocytosis regulated ABCA1 degradation. Surprisingly, reducing caveolin-1 expression significantly decreased ABCA1-mediated cholesterol efflux (Fig. 3 [rid=Fig3] G) despite an increase in total ABCA1 protein levels (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] F). Furthermore, overexpression of caveolin-1 in astrocytes enhanced cholesterol efflux (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] G). 
Cholesterol loading, by adding LDL, led to increased caveolin-1 expression (Fig. 3 [rid=Fig3] H and I) and showed a dose-dependent increase in baby hamster kidney (BHK) cells (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] H).

ABCA1 was mainly expressed in astrocytes and axon-enriched fractions, and lower ABCA1 expression was detected in microglial cells (Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] D). context_description:
Moreover, samples in the paired-end group had many more mappable reads than those in the single-end group ( Table 1 [href=#T1] , Supplementary Fig. 1 [href=this file] ). Indeed, the two groups showed distinct global patterns of pseudogene expression ( Supplementary Fig. 2 [href=this file] ). For each cancer type, we observed generally weak correlations between the expression level of pseudogenes and their WT genes, which is consistent with the previous study ( Supplementary Fig. 3 [href=this file] ). As observed in Kalyana-Sundaram et al. (2012) , we detected some tumor-lineage-specific pseudogenes (296 from the paired-end group and 41 from the single-end group, Supplementary Fig. 4 [href=this file] ). In addition, for three cancer types with available RNA-seq data from nontumor tissue samples, we identified differentially expressed pseudogenes between tumor and nontumor samples (54 in BRCA, 110 in KIRC and 138 in LUSC, Supplementary Fig. 5 [href=this file] ).
For several cancer types with established tumor subtypes, we performed the supervised analysis and revealed substantial numbers of pseudogenes with significant differential expression: 48 in UCEC (endometrioid vs. serous) , 138 in LUSC (basal, classical, primitive and secretory) , 71 in GBM (classical, mesenchymal, neural and proneural) and 547 in BRCA (PAM50 subtypes: luminal A, luminal B, basal-like, Her2-enriched and normal-like) (Methods, Fig. 2a [href=#F2] , Supplementary Data 1 [href=this file] ).
The predictive power of pseudogene expression is comparable to those achieved by the mRNA expression profiles, suggesting that both pseudogene and mRNA expression can classify the UCEC subtypes independently ( Supplementary Fig. 6 [href=this file] ).
Based on the NMF consensus clustering, 837 BRCA samples can be classified into three distinct subtypes: subtype 1 ( = 144), subtype 2 ( = 390), and subtype 3 ( = 303) ( Fig. 4b [href=#F4] , Supplementary Data 2 [href=this file] ).
Based on the 500 pseudogenes with the most variable expression, we were able to classify 446 KIRC samples into two distinct subtypes ( Fig. 5a [href=#F5] , Supplementary Data 3 [href=this file] ). We observed an enrichment of pseudogenes (115 out of 500) with a statistically significant P-value ( < 0.05) ( Fig. 5c [href=#F5] , Supplementary Data 4 [href=this file] ).
To further assess the clinical utility of the observed pseudogene-expression subtypes, we classified the KIRC samples into four risk quartiles based on the risk scores (in terms of overall survival) calculated from the multivariate Cox model, employing only clinical variables: low risk group (Q1, = 110), low-medium risk group (Q2, = 111), medium-high risk group (Q3, = 112), and high risk group (Q4, = 112) (Methods, Supplementary Data 3 [href=this file] ).
To gain some mechanistic insight into how expressed pseudogenes contribute to the observed KIRC pseudogene-expression subtypes, we performed a systematic analysis ( Supplementary Fig. 9a and Supplementary Data 5 [href=this file] ). Among the WT cognate genes with strong positive correlations with their pseudogenes, we noticed that the survival correlations of individual WT genes with prognostic value match the survival pattern of the pseudogene-expression subtypes: WT genes with better prognosis (potentially tumor suppressors, hazard ratio < 1) show higher expression levels in subtype 1 (the better survival group) and the genes with worse prognosis (potentially oncogenes, hazard ratio > 1) show higher expression levels in subtype 2 (the worse survival group, Supplementary Fig. 8b [href=this file] ). Finally, we examined the classic miRNA decoy model as proposed in Poliseno et al. (2010) and identified 38 such candidates ( Methods and Supplementary Data 5 [href=this file] ). One candidate of interest is the potential regulation of a putative tumor suppressor α-catenin (CTNNA1) by the pseudogene PGOHUM00000257111 through competition for up to 9 shared miRNA regulators ( Supplementary Data 5 [href=this file] ). Indeed, the expression levels of PGOHUM00000257111 were significantly higher in cluster 1 (t-test P = 1.48×10-7), which may lead to the elevated levels of CTNNA1 in subtype 1 ( Supplementary Fig. 8b [href=this file] ) and therefore better survival.
Finally, we performed feature selection ( Supplementary Data 6 [href=this file] ) and built the classifier from the whole training set using the best-performing algorithm (with the highest AUC) identified through the cross-validation, and applied it to the test set in order to independently validate the predictive power.

After clustering (Supplementary Fig. 1a–e [this file] ), a total of 37,943 cells were annotated into 23 clusters using a predefined set of marker genes (Supplementary Fig. 1c [this file] ). 
To reveal heterogeneity within oligodendrocytes, we grouped the aforementioned oligodendrocytes into six classes described in a published database , as follows (Fig. 1a [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Fig. 2a [this file] –d and 3a [this file] ): (1) Differentiation-committed oligodendrocyte precursors (COPs) and newly formed oligodendrocytes (NFOL) that express Sox6, Pdgfra, and Cspg4. (2) Myelin-forming oligodendrocytes (MFOL) that express Ctps, Ablims, and Thbs3. (3) Mature oligodendrocytes 1, 2 (MOL 1, 2) that express Il33, Ptgds, and Opalin. (4) Mature oligodendrocytes 3, 4 (MOL 3, 4) that express Klk6, S100b, Anxa5, Cd59a and Mgst3. Moreover, we discovered an additional oligodendrocyte cluster, which gradually increased in the 3-, 6-month-old App KI mice (Fig. 1b–d [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Fig. 2e [this file] ). This cluster was present in the UMAP plot even with down-sampled data (400, 1,200, and 2,400 cells) (Supplementary Fig. 2f [this file] ). Remarkably, we found that this cluster shared some signatures with MOL2, while Alzheimer’s disease risk factors such as C4b, Apoe and Cd74 are strongly expressed (Supplementary Fig. 2c [this file] , 3a [this file] , 3b [this file] , and Source data file). 
We further confirmed the lineage transitions of DAOs and homeostatic MOLs from COP and NFOL in control and AD brains (Fig. 1e–g [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ), but density from the DAO cluster exclusively appeared in 3 and 6-month-old AD brains (Fig. 1 [rid=Fig1] g). 
We reanalyzed previously published single-cell transcriptome datasets from postmortem AD brains (Supplementary Fig. 5a–c [this file] ) . 
Notably, consistent with scRNA-seq results, we observed a significant increase in Mbp + , Cd74+ oligodendrocytes in 3- and 6-month-old App KI and 6-month-old 5xFAD mice, whereas the number of NeuroD1+ post-mitotic neurons significantly decreased (Fig. 2 [rid=Fig2] a, b [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Fig. 6a–c [this file] , and Supplementary Fig. 7a [this file] , b [this file] ). We further confirmed an increase in Cd74+ and Oligo2+ AD-associated oligodendrocytes in App KI mice using flow cytometry (Fig. 2 [rid=Fig2] c, d [rid=Fig2] , and Supplementary Fig. 6d [this file] ). 
Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis revealed that 6-month-old App KI mice exhibited a thinner myelin layer relative to the axon diameter (Fig. 2e [rid=Fig2] and supplementary fig. 8 [this file] ). 
Consistently, we found a significant increase in Mbp+ and Cd74+ DAOs in the hippocampus of premature progeria (6-month-old) and 13-month-old mice (Supplementary Fig. 9a–d [this file] ), whereas the number of NeuroD1-positive post-mitotic neurons decreased in the hippocampus of 13-month-old mice (Supplementary Fig. 9e and f [this file] ). We further confirmed that the genes enriched in DAOs were highly correlated with gene signatures shown in the aged human brain (Supplementary Fig. 10a, b [this file] ), indicating that Cd74-positive DAOs increased in the aged brains and had transcriptional profiles more similar to the aged human brain. 
In particular, we found significant alternations in the transcriptional profiles between DAOs and MOL 3/4 clusters and GO-term of up-regulated genes in DAO versus MOL3/4 showed the interleukin & chemokine production and ERK signaling (Fig. 3 [rid=Fig3] a and c [rid=Fig3] ), which was also confirmed during the disease progression in AD mice brain (Supplementary Fig. 11a, b [this file] ). 
We first identified microglia with a high DAM module score based on previously published DAM signatures (Supplementary Fig. 1e [this file] , 12a, b [this file] ), that gradually increased during AD progression (Fig. 3 [rid=Fig3] e, f [rid=Fig3] , and Supplementary Fig. 12c [this file] ). 
Supplementary Fig. 13a–c [this file] shows efficient inhibition of phosphor 44/42 MAPK signaling in primary oligodendrocytes upon treatment with 200 ng/ml SCH772984, a specific Erk1 and Erk2 inhibitor. Remarkably, oligodendrocytes treated with SCH772984 exhibited a significant increase in Mbp+ branching compared with the controls, whereas the number of Cd74+ cells significantly decreased (Supplementary Fig. 13d [this file] , 13e [this file] , and Fig. 4a–c [rid=Fig4] ). 
First, in order to examine the potential interactions between DAOs and other neuronal cell types, AD DAOs were co-cultured with AD neurons, astrocytes, and microglia treated with SCH772984 (Supplementary Fig. 14a [this file] ). We found that AD DAOs with other neuronal cell types did not increase the number of Mbp+ branches in the presence and absence of SCH772984 treatment (Supplementary Fig. 14b–f [this file] ), suggesting that inhibition of ERK/MAPK signaling in other neuronal cell types did not contribute to the phenotypic changes in DAOs (Fig. 4d–f [rid=Fig4] ). Moreover, to investigate whether other neural cell types can contribute to the AD-associated phenotypes via ERK signaling, each of the neurons, microglia, astrocytes and oligodendrocytes isolated from AD mice were subjected to SCH772984 treatment, and AD pathology was determined after co-culture with the remaining untreated AD neuronal cell types (Supplementary Fig. 15a [this file] ). Remarkably, we found that ERK1/2-inhibited oligodendrocytes significantly diminished the Aβ42/40 ratio in the AD primary neuronal cultures (Supplementary Fig. 15b [this file] ). Also, we observed a decrease in the amyloidogenic processing marker C99 in the AD neuronal cultures with SCH772984 treatment (Supplementary Fig. 15c–e [this file] ), indicating that AD oligodendrocytes predominantly contribute to the pathophysiology of AD via ERK signaling. 
Consistent with previous results, systemic administration of SCH772984 significantly reduced the occurrence of DAOs in the hippocampus of App KI mice (Fig. 5b, c [rid=Fig5] , and Supplementary Fig. 16a–d [this file] ) but not Cd74 + Iba1+ microglia (Supplementary Fig. 16c, d [this file] ). 
Moreover, we confirmed a decrease in the number of Aβ plaques (Fig. 5m, n [rid=Fig5] ), coupled with an increase in the number of NeuroD1+ cells in the SCH772984-treated AD mouse hippocampus (Supplementary Fig. 16e, f [this file] ).

For a small number of trials in which the asymptote of the fitted survival curve was greater than zero (i.e., patients were expected to be alive at the end of the longest follow-up), a three-parameter Weibull distribution consisting of the traditional two-parameter distribution with an additional “cure rate” term had an improved fit (Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] ). 
This is potentially consistent with a two-population hypothesis (Fig. 3a [rid=Fig3] ; Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ). Moreover, a mixture model exhibited no meaningful improvement in fit as compared to a single-distribution for OS data from ICI or control arms in these trials (Fig. 3b [rid=Fig3] ; Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ). This generated the steep decline in PFS values observable in the control and experimental arms of actual ICI trials, and improved fit to PFS distributions, raising mean from 0.93 to 0.98 (Fig. 3c [rid=Fig3] ; Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ; “Methods”). 
A challenge in the analysis of such data is that, when too few events have occurred, nonparametric numeric confidence estimates return non-informative values (usually reported as a value “not reached” or “indeterminate” as illustrated for two different scenarios in Supplementary Fig. 5a [this file] ). We found that 12-month survival estimates were non-informative for 20–40% of OS trial arms, and 23–61% of event-free survival trial arms, with higher failure rates occurring when the sample size was smaller (Supplementary Fig. 5b, c [this file] ). 
For event-free survival (for which 99 event-free survival curves could be compared), the precision of a Weibull-based approach was also greater than a nonparametric approach across all sample sizes, while accuracy was equivalent for small sample sizes (fewer than 40 patients) (Supplementary Fig. 6a [this file] ). 
Thus, parametric fitting of data from 15 patients made a comparably precise and accurate estimate of median PFS as nonparametric analysis of 60 patients (Supplementary Fig. 6b [this file] ). 
We observed that for a representative simulation, a two-parameter Weibull form accurately described the synthetic trial data ( = 0.98; Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] ).

We introduce the HotNet2 (HotNet iffusion riented ubnetworks) algorithm to address the problem of finding significantly mutated subnetworks on large, broad mutation frequency spectrum datasets like Pan-Cancer ( Figure 1c [href=#F1] and Supplementary Figure 3 [href=this file] ). HotNet2 uses a modified diffusion process and considers the source, or directionality, of heat flow in the identification of subnetworks ( Supplementary Figure 4 [href=this file] ).
We combined the resulting subnetworks into 14 consensus subnetworks that were found across different gene scores and networks ( < 0.004, Supplementary Table 3 [href=#SD2] ), plus the condensin complex and CLASP/CLIP proteins ( Supplementary Figure 5 [href=this file] ) that were significant in individual interaction networks ( Supplementary Tables 6,7 [href=#SD2] ). We developed an online interactive viewer (see URLs and Supplementary Figure 6 [href=this file] ) for Pan-Cancer HotNet2 subnetworks.
The subnetworks and linker genes ( Figure 2a [href=#F2] ) include: portions of well-known cancer pathways such as TP53, PI3K, NOTCH, and receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs; Supplementary Figure 7 [href=this file] ), as well as pathways and complexes that have more recently been observed to be important in cancer such as SWI/SNF complex, BAP1 complex, NFE2L2-KEAP1 ( Supplementary Figures 8,9 [href=this file] ), and RUNX1-CBFB core binding complex ( Supplementary Figure 10 [href=this file] ). As gene expression analyses do not allow to accurately discriminate mesenchymal cancer cells from normal stromal cells, we used the allele-specific copy number analysis of tumors (ASCAT) copy number-based tumor purity estimation method to assess tumor cell fraction (Supplementary Fig. 1a [this file] ). To avoid any substantial bias due to non-tumor cell contamination, a stringent purity threshold was determined by applying Wilcoxon test, for which the degree of contamination of claudin-low tumors was not statistically different from that of non-claudin-low tumors, thus enabling a comparable distribution of tumors (Supplementary Fig. 1b [this file] ). Demonstrating an unexpected degree of diversity, only 35.6% of these tumors were classified as TNBCs (Supplementary Fig. 1d [this file] ). This result was not due to the purity selection, as the percentage of TNBCs within all claudin-low tumors was similar before applying the purity threshold (Supplementary Fig. 1c [this file] ). 
Only 17.8% were found in cluster 10, whereas 48.8% and 17.8% were found in integrative clusters 4 and 3, respectively, regardless of tumor purity when compared with non-claudin-low tumors (Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] ). After having previously removed germline copy number variations (CNVs), we analyzed B allele frequency (BAF) and log R ratio (LRR) profiles of single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) localized in genomic regions of deletion (LRR segment mean cutoff value < −0.4) (Fig. 1b [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Fig. 3a, c [this file] ). Consistent with these data, the analysis of somatic mutations highlighted the presence of several point mutations with a variant allele frequency higher than 0.4 (Fig. 1c [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Fig. 3b [this file] ). 
Of note, although these analyses were performed on tumors selected for their high tumor purity, similar data were obtained when studying the whole cohort of claudin-low tumors (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ), further strengthening the characterization of the three claudin-low subgroups. 
Of note, global gene expression signatures demonstrated that the CL2 and CL3 subgroups showed lower luminal- and basal-related signature scores, respectively, compared with luminal- and basal-like breast tumors, while exhibiting a significant enrichment in invasiveness-related signatures (Supplementary Fig. 5a, b [this file] ). 
A claudin-low gene list of 137 genes discriminating the 3 claudin-low subgroups was thus created (Supplementary Fig. 6a, b [this file] ). This expression-based classifier showed an accuracy of 91% when compared with the FGA-based classification using Gaussian finite mixture models (Supplementary Fig. 5c, d [this file] ). Validating the accuracy of our classifier, CL1, CL2, and CL3 tumors and cell lines showed low, moderate, and elevated FGA levels, respectively (Supplementary Fig. 6e, f [this file] ). Of note, we performed a pathway analysis of CL1 discriminant genes that revealed an enrichment in stem cell and pediatric cancer markers (Supplementary Fig. 6g [this file] ). 
Differentially methylated gene analysis was next performed in claudin-low subgroups followed by pathway-enrichment analysis, using over 15,000 pathways available in MSigDB (HALLMARKS, C2, and C5 gene sets) (Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] ). The CL1 subgroup had the highest score for stemness- ( , ) and EMT- (mesenchymal markers: , , ; epithelial markers: , ) related genes, whereas CL2 and CL3 displayed an intermediate score compared with CL1 tumors and with their relative luminal/basal counterparts (Supplementary Fig. 8 [this file] ). 
CL1 tumors mainly display hypomethylated genes that are related to a stemness phenotype, CL2 tumors are overall hypermethylated for genes associated with basal-like features, and CL3 tumors show more heterogeneous methylation profiles with both hypermethylated genes (linked to luminal phenotype) and hypomethylated genes (relative to basal-like characteristics) (see Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] for methodology). 
Additional gene expression analyses performed on METABRIC and TCGA cohorts using two different cellular signature deconvolution algorithms confirmed that these tumors were highly infiltrated by immune cells (Supplementary Fig. 9a–d [this file] ). Nevertheless, unsupervised clustering of microenvironment signatures (immune and non-immune cell subsets) did not allow to discriminate the different claudin-low subgroups (Supplementary Fig. 9e–h [this file] ). 
Supporting our previous results, CL2 and CL3 showed, among the three claudin-low subgroups, the highest score for luminal- (estrogen-related response) and basal-related (proliferation and DDR) signatures, respectively (Supplementary Fig. 10 [this file] ). Furthermore, both CL2 and CL3 showed an activation of the EMT process (Fig. 6a, b, g [rid=Fig6] ), coherent with the downregulation of hormone (in CL2) and proliferation/DDR (in CL3) signatures, compared with luminal and basal tumors, respectively (Supplementary Fig. 10 [this file] and Fig. 6g [rid=Fig6] ). Moreover, CL1 displayed a low proliferation activity and a low DDR (Supplementary Fig. 10a, b, e, f [this file] ), as well as a strong TP53 signaling pathway signature associated with a low frequency of mutations (Fig. 6c, d, g [rid=Fig6] ). 
When stratified by CL subgroups, variations in survival outcome were found, consistent with their presumed origin (Supplementary Fig. 11 [this file] ). 
These traits include (i) a high expression of the ZEB1 EMT-inducing transcription factor and of its target, the methionine sulfoxide reductase MSRB3; (ii) a frequent activation of the RAS-MAPK signaling pathway; (iii) a low activation of the DDR; and (iv) a low frequency of mutations (Supplementary Figs. 8 [this file] and 10 [this file] , and Fig. 6 [rid=Fig6] ). 
The use of a high-purity threshold for tumor selection allowed to circumvent the contamination bias related to the tumor-related centroid (Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] ). 
Finally, the nearest shrunken centroid classifier encompassed 137 genes whose expression discriminate the three FGA-related claudin-low subgroups in METABRIC cohort (Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] ). 
As previously described for genome-wide expression–methylation quantitative trait loci analysis , genes for which methylation -values were negatively correlated with expression values (Spearman’s < 0 and FDR -value < 0.05) were selected for differential methylation analysis (Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] ).

MAP2, RTF2 or Distal/Proximal UTR, Supplementary Table 4 [this file] ) were used to calculate target specific relative expression as 2^(-(CT -CT )) giving rise to normalized transcript levels. 
Statistical testing of NRIs ( Supplementary Table 4 [this file] ) was conducted using by linear mixed models as implemented in the lme4 R package modeling diagnosis or treatment as fixed effect and batch as well as donor (for PSD95 analysis) as random effect. 
All well level density values used can be found in Supplementary Table 4 [this file] .
